Package stincmale.ratmex.meter

Interface RateMeter<S>

  • Type Parameters:
    S - A type that represents statistics.
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    ResettableRateMeter<S>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractNavigableMapRateMeter, AbstractRateMeter, AbstractRingBufferRateMeter, ConcurrentNavigableMapRateMeter, ConcurrentResettableRateMeter, ConcurrentRingBufferRateMeter, NavigableMapRateMeter, RingBufferRateMeter

    public interface RateMeter<S>
    A utility that measures a rate of ticks by counting ticks in a moving time interval.

    Glossary
    Tick
    A tick is any event which is registered via tick(long, long) method.

    Instant
    RateMeter treats instants as the time (number of nanoseconds) elapsed since the start. So an instant is a pair (startNanos, elapsedNanos), but because startNanos is known and fixed, we can equivalently specify an instant via a single value tNanos = startNanos + elapsedNanos (note that tNanos >= startNanos). RateMeter uses tNanos notation instead of (startNanos, elapsedNanos) notation. All nanosecond values are compared as specified by System.nanoTime().

    Sample
    A sample is a pair (tNanos, ticksCount).

    Samples window
    A samples window is a half-closed time interval (rightmostRegisteredInstant - samplesInterval; rightmostRegisteredInstant] (comparison according to System.nanoTime()). Samples window can only be moved to the right and the only way to do this is to call tick(long, long). 

    
                                        (-------movedSamplesWindow----]
                                        |                             |
   (--------samplesWindow--------]      |<------samplesInterval------>|                                              t
 --|-----------------------------|------|-----------------------------|--------------------------------------------->
                                 |                                    |
                             startNanos                             tNanos
                                 |<-----------elapsedNanos----------->|

    Current ticks
    Current ticks are those registered inside the current samples window.

    Rate
    A rate (a.k.a. instant rate, current rate) is calculated based on current ticks and by default is measured in samplesInterval-1, hence a current rate value always equals to a current ticks count.

    For example if samplesInterval is 30ns,
    startNanos is 10ns,
    and the only registered ticks are
    (25ns, 1) (this is tNanos, not tNanos - startNanos),
    (30ns, 1),
    (50ns, 8),
    (60ns, -2),
    then the current rate is
    (8 - 2) / samplesInterval = 6samplesInterval-1 = 6 / 30ns = 0.2ns-1. 

    
       10ns           25ns 30ns                50ns      60ns                                                        t
 --|----|----|----|----1----1----|----|----|----8----|---(-2)--|----|----|----|----|----|----|----|----|----|----|-->
        |                   (--------samplesWindow--------]
    startNanos

    Samples history
    A half-closed interval which is equal to the union of adjacent samples windows. Samples history includes samples registered inside it. The length of a samples history is always a multiple of the length of a samples window (i.e. samplesInterval). 

    
                  (-----------------------------*--------samplesWindow--------]
                                                |                             |
                             leftNanos is not included in samplesWindow       |
                                 but is included in samplesHistory            |
                                                |                             |                                      t
 -----------------|-----------------------------|-----------------------------|------------------------------------->
                  |                         leftNanos                         |
                  |                                                           |
                  |<-------------samplesHistory, historyLength==2------------>|

    Safe samples history
    A part of samples history that includes everything except for the leftmost samples window. It is possible to calculate the rate for any instant inside the safe samples history, or ahead (to the right) of it. The minimal allowed length of samples history is 2samplesInterval because this gives the minimal possible safe samples history with length equal to samplesInterval. 

    
                  (-----------------------------*-----------------------------*--------samplesWindow--------]        t
 -----------------|-----------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------->
                  |                             |                                                           |
                  |                             |<--------------------safeSamplesHistory------------------->|
                  |                                                                                         |
                  |<------------------------- safeSamplesHistory, historyLength==3------------------------->|

    Allowed values
    ticksCount ∈ [Long.MIN_VALUE; Long.MAX_VALUE],
    samplesInterval (in nanos) ∈ [1, Long.MAX_VALUE / (historyLength + 1) - 1],
    tNanos ∈ [startNanos, startNanos - (historyLength + 1) * samplesInterval + Long.MAX_VALUE] (comparison according to System.nanoTime()).

    API notes
    This interface is designed to allow garbage-free implementations and usage scenarios. Methods with RateMeterReading parameter are specifically serve this purpose: they do not create RateMeterReading objects, thus allowing a user to reuse the same RateMeterReading.

    Implementation notes
    Different implementations may conform to different correctness conditions (a.k.a. consistency models) and provide different guarantees on the accuracy. Implementations with weaker guarantees may display better performance because they can sacrifice accuracy for the sake of performance and yet may produce sufficiently accurate results in practice. Implementations are recommended to aim for accuracy on the best-effort basis, but all methods which have analogs with RateMeterReading parameters are allowed to produce approximate results.

    Implementations may not internally use nanosecond time sensitivity (resolution, accuracy, granularity). In fact, there is no sense in using resolution better than the resolution of the timer that is used by a user of RateMeter.

      A size of the samples window.
      long getStartNanos​()
      Returns the starting point that is used to calculate elapsed nanoseconds.
      java.time.Duration getTimeSensitivity​()
      A time sensitivity which affects the behaviour of tick(long, long) method in a way that allows registering a sample at an instant that differs from the specified one not more than by the time sensitivity.
      long rate​()
      Calculates the current rate of ticks measured in samplesInterval-1.
      default double rate​(long tNanos)
      Calculates rate of ticks (measured in samplesInterval-1) as if tNanos were the right boundary of the samples window, if tNanos is ahead of or within the safe samples history; otherwise returns rateAverage().
      double rate​(long tNanos, java.time.Duration unit)
      This method is equivalent to rate(long) but the result is measured in unit-1 instead of samplesInterval-1.
      default RateMeterReading rate​(long tNanos, java.time.Duration unit, RateMeterReading reading)
      This method is equivalent to rate(long, Duration), but provides a complete measured data, while rate(long, Duration) returns only a rate value.
      RateMeterReading rate​(long tNanos, RateMeterReading reading)
      This method is equivalent to rate(long), but provides a complete measured data, while rate(long) returns only a rate value.
      default double rate​(java.time.Duration unit)
      This method is equivalent to rate() but the result is measured in unit-1 instead of samplesInterval-1.
      default RateMeterReading rate​(java.time.Duration unit, RateMeterReading reading)
      This method is equivalent to rate(Duration), but provides a complete measured data, while rate(Duration) returns only a rate value.
      RateMeterReading rate​(RateMeterReading reading)
      This method is equivalent to rate(), but provides a complete measured data, while rate() returns only a rate value.
      default double rateAverage​()
      Calculates an average (mean) rate of ticks (measured in samplesInterval-1) from the start till the rightSamplesWindowBoundary().
      double rateAverage​(long tNanos)
      Calculates an average (mean) rate of ticks (measured in samplesInterval-1) from the start till the tNanos, if tNanos is greater than rightSamplesWindowBoundary(), otherwise returns rateAverage().
      double rateAverage​(long tNanos, java.time.Duration unit)
      This method is equivalent to rateAverage(long) but the result is measured in unit-1 instead of samplesInterval-1.
      default double rateAverage​(java.time.Duration unit)
      This method is equivalent to rateAverage() but the result is measured in unit-1 instead of samplesInterval-1.
      long rightSamplesWindowBoundary​()
      Instant that corresponds to the right border of the samples window.
      java.util.Optional<S> stats​()
      Returns statistics gathered by this RateMeter.

      Registers a sample of count ticks at tNanos instant.

    • Method Detail

      • getStartNanos

        long getStartNanos​()
        Returns the starting point that is used to calculate elapsed nanoseconds.
        Returns:
        The starting point that is used to calculate elapsed nanoseconds.
        See Also:
        System.nanoTime()

      • getSamplesInterval

        java.time.Duration getSamplesInterval​()
        A size of the samples window.
        Returns:
        Duration which is not zero and not negative.

      • getTimeSensitivity

        java.time.Duration getTimeSensitivity​()
        A time sensitivity which affects the behaviour of tick(long, long) method in a way that allows registering a sample at an instant that differs from the specified one not more than by the time sensitivity.

        This behavior may be observed via rightSamplesWindowBoundary(). Hence this method can be considered as an important implementation detail leaked through RateMeter's leaky abstraction.

        Implementation considerations
        It is recommended to use a resolution (accuracy, granularity) of the timer used by a user of RateMeter. For example 200ns may be a good approximation of the System.nanoTime() accuracy (see timers-bench and Nanotrusting the Nanotime for measurements and explanations).

        Returns:
        A positive, i.e. not negative and not zero time sensitivity which is used internally.

      • rightSamplesWindowBoundary

        long rightSamplesWindowBoundary​()
        Instant that corresponds to the right border of the samples window. At the very beginning this is equal to getStartNanos(). This border can be moved to the right via tick(long, long) method.
        Returns:
        The rightmost registered instant.

      • ticksCountTotal

        long ticksCountTotal​()
        Calculates the total number of ticks since the start.
        Returns:
        Total number of ticks.

      • tick

        void tick​(long count,
          long tNanos)
        Registers a sample of count ticks at tNanos instant. If tNanos is greater than current rightSamplesWindowBoundary() then this method moves the samples window such that its right boundary is at tNanos.
        Parameters:
        count - Number of ticks. May be negative, zero, or positive. If zero then the method does nothing, otherwise adds count to the currently registered number of ticks at the specified instant, or just remembers count ticks if no ticks were registered at the specified instant.
        tNanos - An instant (a pair (startNanos, elapsedNanos)) at which count ticks need to be registered.

      • rateAverage

        default double rateAverage​()
        Calculates an average (mean) rate of ticks (measured in samplesInterval-1) from the start till the rightSamplesWindowBoundary().
        Returns:
        The same value as rateAverage(rightSamplesWindowBoundary()).

      • rateAverage

        default double rateAverage​(java.time.Duration unit)
        This method is equivalent to rateAverage() but the result is measured in unit-1 instead of samplesInterval-1.
        Parameters:
        unit - A time interval to use as a unit. Must not be zero or negative.
        Returns:
        Average rate of ticks measured in unit-1.

      • rateAverage

        double rateAverage​(long tNanos)
        Calculates an average (mean) rate of ticks (measured in samplesInterval-1) from the start till the tNanos, if tNanos is greater than rightSamplesWindowBoundary(), otherwise returns rateAverage().
        Parameters:
        tNanos - An effective (imaginary) right boundary of the samples window.
        Returns:
        Average rate of ticks or 0 if tNanos is equal to getStartNanos().

      • rateAverage

        double rateAverage​(long tNanos,
                   java.time.Duration unit)
        This method is equivalent to rateAverage(long) but the result is measured in unit-1 instead of samplesInterval-1.
        Parameters:
        tNanos - An effective (imaginary) right boundary of the samples window.
        unit - A time interval to use as a unit. Must not be zero or negative.
        Returns:
        Average rate of ticks measured in unit-1.

      • rate

        long rate​()
        Calculates the current rate of ticks measured in samplesInterval-1. Conceptually, the returned value is equal to rate(rightSamplesWindowBoundary()), but with both methods rightSamplesWindowBoundary() and rate(long) executed atomically.
        Returns:
        The current rate of ticks.

      • rate

        RateMeterReading rate​(RateMeterReading reading)
        This method is equivalent to rate(), but provides a complete measured data, while rate() returns only a rate value.
        Parameters:
        reading - A RateMeterReading to be filled with the measured data.
        Returns:
        reading filled with the measured data.

      • rate

        default double rate​(java.time.Duration unit)
        This method is equivalent to rate() but the result is measured in unit-1 instead of samplesInterval-1.
        Parameters:
        unit - A time interval to use as a unit. Must not be zero or negative.
        Returns:
        Current rate of ticks measured in unit-1.

      • rate

        default RateMeterReading rate​(java.time.Duration unit,
                              RateMeterReading reading)
        This method is equivalent to rate(Duration), but provides a complete measured data, while rate(Duration) returns only a rate value.
        Parameters:
        unit - A time interval to use as a unit. Must not be zero or negative.
        reading - A RateMeterReading to be filled with the measured data.
        Returns:
        reading filled with the measured data.

      • rate

        default double rate​(long tNanos)
        Calculates rate of ticks (measured in samplesInterval-1) as if tNanos were the right boundary of the samples window, if tNanos is ahead of or within the safe samples history; otherwise returns rateAverage().
        Parameters:
        tNanos - An effective (imaginary) right boundary of the samples window.

        Parameters:

      • stats

        Returns:
